data.title: Electric Dusk by Leon Thomas | Album Review
data.meta_description: If you were anything like me in the early 2010’s, you thought Andre from Nickelodeon’s Victorious was the coolest motherfucker, he continues to prove that
data.text:
Subscribe to my substack to see more reviews (pls) :)

If you were anything like me in the early 2010’s, you thought Andre from Nickelodeon’s Victorious was the coolest motherfucker. He could play any instrument, act, sing and was, arguably (given the stature of his costars) the most talented of the bunch, at least musically. Leon Thomas has built a producing repertoire that would match anyone in the game including work with Snoh Aalegra, 6lack, Ariana Grande, and perhaps most notably, Drake on Certified Lover Boy a couple of years ago.

Electric Dust, his debut album with Motown Records, looks to put Thomas in the spotlight after, largely, making a living behind the scenes or in support of another. Leaning on incredibly refined vocality, a knack for catchy songwriting, and at times, minimalist, yet intricate, production tactics, Thomas creates smooth, drug-induced sexscapades far removed from the innocence of his Nickelodeon days and, fittingly, illuminates his musicality on its largest stage thus far.

Distinctly influenced by late 90’s and early 00’s R&B, Thomas is a slurried combination of Usher, Ginuwine, and Luther Vandross as he croons in a fashion tailored to the contemporary dating scene, including sneaky links and the facade of…
